10.92.text:
I'm the curator of Dutch and Flemish
paintings here at the National Gallery.

18.16.text:
and very great pleasure of curating
this exhibition on 'Dutch flowers'.

24.80.text:
And one of the greatest pleasures
in organising this exhibition

30.96.text:
was the opportunity to work
with the gentleman standing here,

36.28.text:
Brian and his wife Janice have collected,
over a number of years,

42.80.text:
a wonderful collection of Dutch
flower paintings of the 17th century.

51.08.text:
put a number of these paintings
on long-term loan to the gallery

54.48.text: and they are featured in this exhibition.

58.76.text:
Brian has agreed to engage
in conversation with me today,

64.64.text:
so that I can grill him a bit
about his collection,

68.96.text: about the paintings in his collection

71.32.text: and share that information with you.

79.28.text:
Thank you, Betsy, for such a generous
and charming introduction, yes.

83.36.text: I await the third degree at your hands.

86.24.text: I'll be kind. I'll be kind.

88.44.text:
Brian and I, we don't
like each other at all, by the way.

91.20.text: Let me just set that out.

93.32.text:
OK, my first question
is pretty straight-forward and that is,

97.60.text:
when did you start collecting
Dutch flower paintings, and why?

102.20.text:
Well, I began collecting Dutch
flower paintings about 25 years ago.

106.96.text:
"Why?" is a slightly
more complicated question.

111.36.text:
I guess I wanted to make a collection
of things that told a story,

116.40.text:
And it could have been a narrative
that began in 1880

120.00.text:
with impressionist paintings
going through into the modern period,

123.28.text:
or it could have been a narrative
as this is,

126.16.text:
beginning in about 1605
and ending 120 years later.

130.76.text:
And as it turned out,
I chose Dutch flower paintings.

134.12.text: So you wanted to create a narrative,

137.16.text: but had you been attracted to flowers

142.16.text: or botany or horticulture prior to that?

147.12.text:
I'm sorry to say it wasn't, no.
This was entirely a matter of chance.

152.48.text:
I picked up a book by a guy
called Laurence Bol

157.04.text:
And this was long before I had
any interest in collecting paintings

160.88.text:
or indeed ever expected
that I might one day be able to do so.

166.16.text:
and it told the story of how
Dutch flower paintings in the 17th century

175.88.text:
and carried on through to the van Huysums
that we see here today.

179.60.text:
So there we are.
That's what kindled the interest.

183.00.text:
And we have, I think,
from our own collection, not from yours,

186.80.text:
two paintings by Bosschaert
in the exhibition,

189.28.text:
one of which is the large painting
in the centre on that wall

193.64.text:
and then the one immediately
to the left of it.

198.32.text:
What was the first painting
that you bought? Do you remember?

201.48.text:
I do, yes. My first painting
wasn't one painting. It was two.

205.60.text:
And that was the pair of paintings
by Beert, which sit next to...

209.04.text:
- Fabulous.
- ...my Bosschaert, which is on the right.

212.00.text:
- So I am going to take that away one day.
- OK.

216.00.text: And if you can just look at those,

218.16.text:
they are actually
very unusual paintings for their time

222.92.text:
because most of the artists
that were painting around that time

226.52.text:
did very meticulous rendering,
so exactly what you were looking at.

231.24.text:
Their aim was to be
as true to life as possible.

235.44.text:
Beert didn't really attempt that.
He thought, "Let's have a go."

238.64.text:
And you can sort of see
the bit of impressionist appearance -

244.64.text: it's those two paintings over there.

246.72.text:
And, for me, that struck a note,
it struck a chord.

254.16.text: maybe having two in one purchase,

258.00.text:
that sort of already gave you
a little bit of a collection.

265.04.text:
One of the things I particularly love
about those Beert paintings

268.64.text:
is the fact that they still have survived
as a pair, as a set,

275.96.text: And also the fact that with Beert,

278.64.text: you see him starting to try

281.48.text:
and get a sense of 3-dimensionality
in the paintings

285.52.text:
by highlighting the paintings in the front
and shadowing the ones to either side.

292.20.text:
So there's a nice sense already in those
paintings of how the genre is developing.

301.20.text:
what appealed to you about the Beert
paintings was the impressionistic quality,

306.68.text:
but what are the other qualities that you
might look for in a particular painting?

312.84.text:
Well, of course the reason why
this collection exists at all

316.76.text:
is to illustrate the development
of the art

319.72.text: as it went along through the 17th century.

323.68.text:
And I'm interested in the way things
start, develop and then finish,

335.36.text:
the very early paintings
are mainly like illustrations, almost,

344.12.text:
arranged in such a way
to look like they populate a vase.

349.56.text:
And they don't really have
a 3-dimensional component

356.32.text:
whereas as the century went on,
they got much better at it.

360.24.text:
If you look at the Rachel Ruysch paintings
on our left here...

365.44.text:
She was very adept
at rendering these 3-dimensions

369.24.text:
and that's one of the things
that they achieved as they went along.

372.64.text:
So as your flower paintings develop
over a century or so,

378.12.text:
it's almost like a science -
they just get better at what they do.

383.36.text:
That, I have to say,
was one of the great joys

386.76.text: when I first visited you in your home

389.40.text:
to stand in a room
and literally be in the middle

394.16.text:
of the history of
17th century Dutch flower painting.

398.40.text: It was just an absolute delight,

401.44.text:
which I've tried
to recreate here a little bit

404.28.text: thanks to paintings from your collection.

408.04.text:
And one of the things that I've really
enjoyed about having the opportunity

414.36.text:
to integrate works
from your collection with ours

417.92.text: is how they speak to each other

419.60.text: and how the works that you've lent to us

424.68.text:
amplify our own collection
in really wonderful and dynamic ways.

430.04.text:
For example, this painting,
immediately to my side...

436.20.text:
- Left...
- I've a problem with left and right.

439.40.text:
...is by Rachel Ruysch,
as is the one next to it.

443.68.text:
This is from
the National Gallery's collection

446.48.text:
and that one is from
the Capstick collection.

449.72.text:
Just to be able to see how the artist
develops over the course of her career

455.24.text:
between those two markers that we now have
is really, really amazing.

463.08.text: She was a very productive lady.

465.64.text:
She continued to paint
until she was into her 80s, I believe.

469.28.text:
And she was also remarkable as a woman
of the 17th century and early 18th century

474.60.text: because she was an independent artist.

479.76.text:
she went travelling throughout Europe
and worked as a court painter.

485.68.text:
- Yes, in Germany.
- In Germany, yes.

488.44.text:
Which is unbelievable
for the late 17th to early 18th century.

493.28.text: Ladies were painted into a corner

495.76.text:
because they weren't allowed
to paint the human figure.

499.00.text:
They weren't allowed
to go to a life class

501.96.text:
because that might upset
their sensibilities.

508.00.text: So that's why she would have chosen that.

513.92.text: Now, back to the list of questions here...

517.92.text:
Do you have a particular favourite
painting in your collection?

523.20.text:
I suppose the one
that we're standing in front of

528.72.text: And this is a most unusual painting.

532.16.text:
It was painted somewhere
around the middle of the century,

535.04.text:
and you can see it is totally different
both in its conception and execution

540.00.text: to pretty much all the others here.

544.24.text:
if somebody said,
"This is a 19th century painting

549.60.text:
you wouldn't suddenly turn around and say,
"That's impossible."

552.76.text:
So it's an idiom and a style
which is quite out of character

558.20.text:
with what led up to it
and what followed afterwards,

564.28.text:
It's by Dirck de Bray, a Haarlem painter
from a family of painters.

569.48.text:
I think his father and brothers
and his uncle were also painters.

574.72.text: He himself painted primarily still lives

578.76.text: and as a comparatively young man...

583.04.text:
...entered a monastery, I believe,
as a lay brother.

586.52.text:
A number of his paintings have
a spiritual, Catholic dimension to them.

592.28.text: But I think all of them

594.24.text:
have this wonderful
almost spookiness to them

600.48.text:
because they are so immediate,
so striking in their depiction.

607.48.text:
In addition to 19th century
impressionist works,

611.32.text:
they also make me think
of Spanish still lives

620.92.text:
many of them took the same
rather low point of view,

625.88.text:
and what you end up with
is a much more massive appearance

629.76.text: than you do if you take it higher up.

632.28.text:
Also, I think one thing that appeals to
viewers particularly about this painting

643.88.text: like Bosschaert or de Heem do.

648.72.text:
This is a bunch of flowers stuck in a vase
as you or I might do.

654.16.text:
We go out into the garden and we pick
whatever looks beautiful and in bloom.

659.88.text:
We come back
and just put them in the vase

663.00.text: and a few blossoms fall off,

665.28.text:
and a ladybird and bumblebee
have come in along with it.

668.88.text:
And we see that same wonderful immediacy
in this painting.

675.68.text:
I don't think he set out
to paint in the tradition of anybody.

678.72.text:
I think he just wanted
to paint a flower picture

682.80.text:
And I think the de Bray family
painted all sorts, didn't they?

686.60.text:
- They did.
- They did portraits and what have you.

688.96.text:
Yes, it's really a wonderful
diverse artistic dynasty.

693.32.text: And I came by this picture by accident.

696.68.text: I never have accidents like this.

699.72.text: Well, it wasn't that much of an accident,

701.60.text:
but the then director, some years ago,
of the Rijksmuseum

706.04.text: was having dinner with a friend of mine,

707.92.text:
who told him that she had this friend
who collected flower paintings.

712.44.text:
"Oh," he said. "He should go
and have a look at this de Bray."

716.32.text:
The word got back to me
that this was the case, and then I did,

722.00.text:
That could very easily have been part
of somebody else's collection.

725.40.text:
You could have begged off
that dinner party

727.56.text:
and somebody else
would have had the painting.

737.28.text:
Now, we've talked about
a particular favourite in your collection.

742.64.text:
Do you have
a particular favourite painting

748.84.text: Oh, gosh. That I would nick off with?

751.32.text: Perhaps we can do a swap.

753.20.text:
Well, I think possibly this Walscappelle
here on my right.

756.88.text: This is a wonderful painting by him.

763.28.text:
...complicated painting
that I've seen of his.

765.76.text:
And you can see
these wonderful arabesques,

769.72.text:
And I think I'm right in saying that he
was a tutor to Rachel Ruysch, wasn't he?

774.48.text:
- I think so, yes.
- I believe so.

776.28.text: He was her tutor, in fact.

778.28.text:
Well, it's interesting
that you picked that painting

782.12.text:
as the one which, I'm sorry I can't allow
you to take away with you,

787.36.text: because it's actually thanks to you

789.96.text:
and the loan of the paintings
occasioning this exhibition

794.16.text:
that we took a second look
at that painting.

797.76.text:
And prior to the planning
for this exhibition,

802.04.text:
the painting had been obscured, really,
by a very discoloured varnish.

807.84.text:
The painting itself
is in an absolutely superb state.

813.08.text: But we were looking at the painting,

816.44.text:
came up with this amazing
17th century tortoiseshell frame.

822.24.text:
He said, "Look, I've got this great frame.
Do you have a painting it might fit?"

826.16.text:
And I said,
"Well, we have this flowers still life,"

830.08.text:
And I said, "That frame
makes the painting look kind of dingy."

836.40.text:
...Morwenna Blewett,
who is one of our restorers,

839.92.text: did a beautiful cleaning of this painting,

842.12.text:
and she said it was so easy,
that there was absolutely nothing to do,

849.72.text:
the National Gallery
has a whole new painting, I think.

853.56.text:
- And that one...
- It's a great one.

855.32.text:
Yes, it's one of my favourites, too,
to look at

859.04.text:
because of all the little insects
crawling in and out,

865.56.text:
Particularly, in the lower
left-hand corner of the arrangement,

870.44.text:
you can see a caterpillar
dangling from its bit of silk,

876.68.text: The fineness of that artistic detail...

881.60.text:
- Yes, I like these paintings.
- Yes.

884.28.text:
And I think you'd agree
that they do show to advantage

887.92.text:
by being exhibited alongside others
of the same genre.

891.88.text:
You get more out of them individually
because they're in a crowd

895.80.text:
than you do
if it were just one amongst...

898.20.text: Just like the bouquet of flowers itself.

903.48.text:
As you've formed a collection
over 25 years or so,

909.00.text:
has your understanding of the field
of Dutch flower painting changed, evolved?

915.64.text:
Do you think differently about it now
than you did a couple of decades ago?

922.60.text:
because of course as you collect,
you study,

924.80.text:
and as you study, you learn more,
at least if you can remember it.

928.64.text:
Yes, I know a lot more about it
than when I began, that's fair to say.

933.88.text:
What I do think about is many people
now collect modern paintings.

940.28.text: Contemporary seems to rule the world.

943.60.text: So you have to ask yourself,

944.96.text:
what is the role
of Dutch flower painting -

948.88.text: what's its relevance to the modern viewer?

955.04.text: I don't know if you feel

958.04.text: Well, it's been interesting to me

960.16.text:
because when I proposed
doing this exhibition here,

964.96.text:
I thought, "Well,
it will appeal to some people,"

968.12.text:
but what's really surprised me is how
amazingly popular the show has been.

974.08.text:
And if any of you
have been here more than once,

976.36.text:
you'll know almost any time you come in,
it's massively crowded in here,

980.44.text: which is fantastic - we love that.

983.76.text: But what has also interested me

985.72.text:
is the range of people who visit the show
and are interested in it -

992.08.text:
people who are primarily interested
in gardening

995.36.text: or from a scientific point of view,

998.28.text:
or younger people who come in
and sometimes despite themselves

1004.12.text:
find themselves intrigued
by these paintings

1007.40.text:
and just pinpoint the bumblebee,
the ladybird, anything...

1011.88.text:
But they realise that there is something
of interest in the paintings.

1017.48.text:
And one project
that we did recently...

1022.60.text:
They did an amazing reproduction
in flowers

1032.80.text:
And I don't know if any of you
had the opportunity to see that,

1036.80.text: but that was, from my perspective,

1039.40.text:
a really wonderful way of expressing
the beauty of these paintings

1048.20.text:
And I think that inspired a lot of people
who might not ordinarily have done so

1053.12.text:
to come in and have a look
at the paintings themselves.

1057.72.text:
So I think these paintings continue
to be very relevant to viewers today

1064.36.text:
and in some respects,
perhaps more so than subject pictures.

1070.28.text:
You don't have to know biblical history
or mythology or obscure allegories

1076.48.text: to be able to fall in love with these.

1079.84.text:
And also I think that
they do technically meet modern painting

1084.88.text:
to a greater degree
than you might at first think

1090.80.text:
...even the most abstract
and modern painting -

1093.12.text: let's take a Bridget Riley, for example -

1095.60.text:
is just an arrangement of colours
and shapes

1100.76.text:
And all the colours and shapes
in these flower paintings

1106.20.text: The artist has thought about them.

1108.96.text:
And the shapes, too, are something
that have been carefully arranged

1116.44.text: Yes, I'm glad you brought that up,

1118.04.text:
because that's something that I think
people are only aware of subliminally -

1123.68.text:
how the artists manipulate colour
and shape and form

1128.88.text: to really pull the arrangement together,

1133.64.text:
and one painting that I always think of is
your painting by Rachel Ruysch,

1139.48.text:
which has these markers, if you will,
of a beautiful salmon pink,

1146.00.text: and you see touches of it throughout.

1148.04.text: Even down here in the honeysuckle,

1151.36.text: she has brought in touches of that pink

1154.56.text:
to unite that
with the rest of the composition.

1157.72.text: It's subtle but it's absolutely beautiful.

1161.80.text: So I think those formal lessons

1166.48.text:
are something that people
can take away, as well.

1170.24.text:
And that very painting
used to hang in a room

1173.76.text: which was next to a room,

1175.16.text:
which had
a big Bridget Riley painting in it.

1177.56.text:
And it was actually quite instructive
to look at these two together

1181.00.text:
and turn over in your mind
how much things have changed

1186.28.text:
and yet also
how little things have changed.

1191.84.text:
So we should add a Bridget Riley
to our collection.

1194.20.text:
- I think you should, yes.
- OK.

1196.84.text:
Thank you all very much for coming.
I hope you've enjoyed it.

1211.40.text: May I say a big thank you to Betsy

1213.32.text:
and her colleagues here
at the National Gallery

1218.20.text: I think it's a perfect size

1220.60.text:
and it does as good a job
as anybody could do

1224.80.text:
of telling the story of flower painting
over this period,

1227.96.text:
so congratulations and thank you
to you and your team.
